translation.title: Twelve Discourses on the Ganges River, Etc.

segments.en: 51–62. Twelve Discourses on the Ganges River, Etc.

segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
segments.en: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

segments.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
segments.en: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
segments.en: And how does a mendicant who develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti vitthāretabbaṃ.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”
(To be expanded for each of the different rivers as in SN 45.91–102.)
Six on slanting to the east,
and six on slanting to the ocean;
and that’s how this chapter is recited.
